description: This series examines the challenges companies face while supporting a bring your own device (BYOD) model. Each episode explores a potential mobile vulnerability and then explores methods to mitigate attacks exploiting that vulnerability. The series uses a hands-on approach actually demonstrating how each compromise works to help better inform systems administrators as to how these compromises occur.

name: Mobile Security
subtitle: Mobile device risks and mitigation

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss and demonstrate the exposure we have from unmanned mobile devices within a managed network.  Don describes some of the problems with them as well as the possible attacks.  He then demonstrates the way built security is working to protect itself on an Apple device by segregating applications and isolatingthe communication between application and the iOS and not allowing direct communication between applications.
episodes.title: Exposure from Unmanaged Mobile Device
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.664
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.664 --> 00:00:03.458
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.458 --> 00:00:03.977
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:03.977 --> 00:00:07.922
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.922 --> 00:00:11.010
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.010 --> 00:00:12.486
>> Welcome to ITProTV,

7
00:00:12.486 --> 00:00:17.660
you're watching emergent technology
security demonstrations.

8
00:00:17.660 --> 00:00:21.300
We're specifically gonna be diving
into the realm of taking look at

9
00:00:21.300 --> 00:00:24.200
exposures that we can get
from unmanaged devices.

10
00:00:24.200 --> 00:00:27.950
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and here to
help us out is gonna be Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:29.300
Don, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:30.236
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:30.236 --> 00:00:32.309
And yeah,
in this episode like Ronnie said,

14
00:00:32.309 --> 00:00:35.419
we're gonna take a look at what it
means to us, as administrators,

15
00:00:35.419 --> 00:00:38.880
if we have to deal with a network that
allows for unmanaged mobile devices.

16
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.279
And, let's start right there with what
the heck is an unmanaged mobile device and

17
00:00:42.279 --> 00:00:44.110
we'll kinda get into the risk afterwards.

18
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:48.695
We have this new movement going on
right now that's called the BYOD or

19
00:00:48.695 --> 00:00:50.920
bring your own device movement.

20
00:00:50.920 --> 00:00:54.504
In the past, like when I think about it,
when I got out of college,

21
00:00:54.504 --> 00:00:57.128
got my first IT job and
went to work for a company,

22
00:00:57.128 --> 00:01:00.510
they issued me a company laptop and
I had a company desktop.

23
00:01:00.510 --> 00:01:02.731
And so, when I was at work I
used the company desktop and

24
00:01:02.731 --> 00:01:05.050
when I was at home I
used the company laptop.

25
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:08.290
And then, after a little while I
was issued a company cellphone.

26
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:12.400
And, if I may work phone calls
I use my work cellphone.

27
00:01:12.400 --> 00:01:16.050
And, if I made personal calls,
I use my personal cellphone if I

28
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:18.070
had even one back then I
don't think I even have one.

29
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:20.980
So, that's how it was back in the day.

30
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:22.530
Well the nice part about that is,

31
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:26.860
because these were work devices, they were
completely controlled by the company.

32
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:29.130
The company had total control and

33
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:33.610
they could dictate what applications were
allowed to run, what permissions I had.

34
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:35.650
Every aspect of that device, and

35
00:01:35.650 --> 00:01:37.959
that device's security was
dictated by the company.

36
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:43.080
But, over time, right,
we had a lot of people wear it like me,

37
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:46.260
I used a BlackBerry for ten years,
I used a BlackBerry and

38
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:48.360
just thought it was the greatest thing.

39
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:51.450
And then the iPhone came out and
the iPhone did so

40
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:53.150
much more than the BlackBerry did.

41
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:56.169
And then, the Android phones came out and
they did so

42
00:01:56.169 --> 00:01:59.404
much more and
I wanted to switch to one of those, right?

43
00:01:59.404 --> 00:02:00.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, I went and bought my own.

44
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:04.730
I did the first generation iPhone and
then the first generation Android phone.

45
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:09.350
And now, I had these phones that
I like better than my work phone.

46
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:11.850
And when I got to the office,
I didn't wanna use the work phone.

47
00:02:11.850 --> 00:02:13.030
I wanna use my phone.
>> [LAUGH]

48
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:14.210
>> Or, maybe I had a laptop

49
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:18.220
that was better than the one they issued
me for work and I wanted to use my own.

50
00:02:18.220 --> 00:02:22.850
But I couldn't because at the office,
they required us to use the work device,

51
00:02:22.850 --> 00:02:25.670
right, that ensured security.

52
00:02:25.670 --> 00:02:27.170
But that started to change.

53
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:31.200
In the last five to ten years, companies
have started saying, wait a minute.

54
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:35.700
If these people wanna buy their own
phones and they're willing to pay for

55
00:02:35.700 --> 00:02:37.460
it, we could save money.

56
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:41.700
We could let them bring their
own device and use it for work.

57
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:42.630
This is genius.

58
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:44.195
Now we don't,
we don't have to do warranties,

59
00:02:44.195 --> 00:02:45.810
we don't have to do any of that stuff.

60
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:48.050
They pay for it and they're willing
to do it, and they're happy to do it,

61
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:51.202
'cause they get the device they
want.That's a, that's a win win, right?

62
00:02:51.202 --> 00:02:54.400
Company says, people get the device
they want, that's perfect.

63
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:55.880
But it comes with a risk.

64
00:02:55.880 --> 00:02:59.360
And the risk is,
when somebody brings their own device,

65
00:02:59.360 --> 00:03:03.440
the company doesn't control it,
they can't control what apps are on it.

66
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:08.196
They can't control whether it's secure or
not, whether it's being updated.

67
00:03:08.196 --> 00:03:10.070
They can't control any of that.

68
00:03:10.070 --> 00:03:12.720
And now, you might have people who yeah
they're bringing their own device,

69
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:14.240
you save a little money.

70
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.150
But, they compromise your network, right?

71
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:22.000
We can really run some big risks by
allowing these unmanaged devices.

72
00:03:22.000 --> 00:03:26.080
And so, when that happens,
what are some of our biggest risks?

73
00:03:26.080 --> 00:03:29.950
Well, the biggest risk is leaking
your corporate data, right.

74
00:03:29.950 --> 00:03:31.892
And nowhere do we see
this more than email.

75
00:03:31.892 --> 00:03:36.331
All you have to do is turn on the news to
find out that celebrity acts or politician

76
00:03:36.331 --> 00:03:40.990
wise had their email compromised and
some of these read through all of it.

77
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:45.785
That, if I'm checking my company
email on my personal phone, and

78
00:03:45.785 --> 00:03:49.810
my personal phone gets stolen or
gets lost, and

79
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:55.560
it wasn't secured, somebody who finds that
phone, now has access to all of my email.

80
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:57.380
And what can the company do about it?

81
00:03:57.380 --> 00:03:59.702
Nothing at that point,
the device is already gone, right?

82
00:03:59.702 --> 00:04:01.930
They lost their opportunity to control it.

83
00:04:01.930 --> 00:04:06.080
That should have been a managed device,
one that the company controlled, but

84
00:04:06.080 --> 00:04:07.140
it wasn't.

85
00:04:07.140 --> 00:04:10.770
And in super critical high secure
environments, it will be a device, right?

86
00:04:10.770 --> 00:04:13.890
Think about the president right,
when President Obama was elected,

87
00:04:13.890 --> 00:04:15.310
or President Trump,

88
00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:18.430
the news made a big deal out of both
of them with their cell phones.

89
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:20.670
They had their personal cell
phones they really liked.

90
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:22.900
And the government had to switch
them to one of the black phones.

91
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:28.580
The secure phones, because just a regular
consumer grade phone is not gonna do for

92
00:04:28.580 --> 00:04:32.255
the President of the US so,
they had to switch to a secure phone.

93
00:04:32.255 --> 00:04:36.770
That is a reality, right, for
a high security environments.

94
00:04:36.770 --> 00:04:40.580
But if you're a medium size company,
or even a large business,

95
00:04:40.580 --> 00:04:43.320
you can save a lot of money by having
people bring their own devices,

96
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:44.580
you just have to be smart about it.

97
00:04:44.580 --> 00:04:46.330
You have to secure them, protect them, and

98
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:48.850
ensure those devices
are configured in a secure manner.

99
00:04:48.850 --> 00:04:52.070
And the best way to do
that is to manage them.

100
00:04:52.070 --> 00:04:54.750
Now in the next episode, we're gonna take
a look at actually using what's call

101
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:58.280
mobile device management,
allowing us to manage those devices.

102
00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:02.030
But before we get in to that, let's talk
a little bit about the security features

103
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:05.740
in the phones themselves that are supposed
to be helping us secure things.

104
00:05:05.740 --> 00:05:07.880
>> All right so, Don, help us out here.

105
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:11.344
Now that we've got these types
of our own unmanaged devices,

106
00:05:11.344 --> 00:05:14.807
what are some of the attacks that
we're really looking out for

107
00:05:14.807 --> 00:05:17.486
when we're doing this
inside of our networks?

108
00:05:17.486 --> 00:05:20.928
>> Okay, so I mentioned not really
an attack, but a risk a minute ago.

109
00:05:20.928 --> 00:05:22.560
I said,
what if somebody loses their phone?

110
00:05:22.560 --> 00:05:26.680
I could find the phone and exploit it or
get the data out of that phone.

111
00:05:26.680 --> 00:05:29.130
Well, that's not really
a purposeful attack.

112
00:05:29.130 --> 00:05:30.330
That's a chance occurrence.

113
00:05:30.330 --> 00:05:32.390
I just happened to find a phone, great.

114
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:36.500
But if somebody wants to target your
company and they know that you're using

115
00:05:36.500 --> 00:05:39.570
unmanaged devices, devices that have
been brought in by end users and

116
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:44.250
they're managing themselves then, there's
a ton of attacks that are available.

117
00:05:44.250 --> 00:05:49.220
They can target them through a number of
things like Rouge App Stores and push

118
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:53.440
Trojan Horses and malware and things like
that onto a phone to start tracking and

119
00:05:53.440 --> 00:05:55.500
leaking data out of that device.

120
00:05:55.500 --> 00:05:57.730
A remote exploit is probably
one of the biggest risks.

121
00:05:57.730 --> 00:06:00.224
We'll see in another
demonstration coming up.

122
00:06:00.224 --> 00:06:04.624
We've got jailbreaking end users
will sometimes intentionally

123
00:06:04.624 --> 00:06:09.090
make their phones less secure,
right, take an iOS device.

124
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:15.080
When you buy an iPhone or an iPad, an iOS
device, it can only run applications

125
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:19.600
pulled from the Apple App Store,
from the iTunes App Store, or whatever.

126
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:24.430
Or, applications that have been digitally
signed by a trusted company, so

127
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:27.310
a company can push their own applications
without going through the app store.

128
00:06:27.310 --> 00:06:31.071
But everything else has come to the app
store unless the user jailbreaks

129
00:06:31.071 --> 00:06:31.830
their phone.

130
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:34.940
If they jailbreak it,
now they can install apps from anywhere.

131
00:06:34.940 --> 00:06:38.360
And maybe they wanna run things
like video game emulators.

132
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:40.360
You can't run those on an iPhone normally.

133
00:06:40.360 --> 00:06:44.220
But you can pull them from these
alternative app stores if you jailbreak.

134
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:47.980
And the risk there is, when you jailbreak,
you're weakening the security of the phone

135
00:06:47.980 --> 00:06:50.860
and that can be taken advantage of very,
very easily.

136
00:06:50.860 --> 00:06:53.630
That's something we just can't
allow in a corporate environment,

137
00:06:53.630 --> 00:06:54.910
weaken security too much.

138
00:06:56.090 --> 00:07:00.420
Surveillance, if an attacker gets
physical access to a phone, even for

139
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:04.270
a moment ,there's a number of different
exploits they can apply to the phone,

140
00:07:04.270 --> 00:07:06.370
to set it up for
remote surveillance, right?

141
00:07:06.370 --> 00:07:11.142
And I'll show it in an episode later
on here, where we take a phone and

142
00:07:11.142 --> 00:07:15.686
we remotely exploit it,
we inject a malware into it via webpage.

143
00:07:15.686 --> 00:07:18.878
And once that's done, we can open up
a session, and do things like turn on

144
00:07:18.878 --> 00:07:22.520
the microphone, and listen to what's
going on on that phone, in that area.

145
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:27.140
We can record what's on the camera,
we can send text messages from that phone.

146
00:07:27.140 --> 00:07:29.075
You can do all sorts of things, remotely.

147
00:07:29.075 --> 00:07:31.715
And from a surveillance perspective,
it's perfect

148
00:07:31.715 --> 00:07:35.455
because you've got a GPS on the phone,
so you can track where people are going.

149
00:07:35.455 --> 00:07:36.775
You've got a microphone,
you've got a camera.

150
00:07:36.775 --> 00:07:39.645
So now, you've got eyes and
ears on the person.

151
00:07:39.645 --> 00:07:44.085
You know exactly where they are,
all because that phone got exploited.

152
00:07:44.085 --> 00:07:45.177
We definitely don't want that.

153
00:07:45.177 --> 00:07:48.896
You might have security personnel that
monitor your physical building, and

154
00:07:48.896 --> 00:07:52.670
if they're bringing their own device and
those device is being compromised,

155
00:07:52.670 --> 00:07:56.272
now someone could determine where
the security guards or in a given time and

156
00:07:56.272 --> 00:07:58.929
use that as part of a physical
break in unto a facility.

157
00:07:58.929 --> 00:08:01.046
Those are things that
aren't just possible,

158
00:08:01.046 --> 00:08:03.551
these are things that have
already happened, right?

159
00:08:03.551 --> 00:08:05.730
There are documented cases
of these events occurring.

160
00:08:05.730 --> 00:08:08.308
So definitely something
we need to be aware of.

161
00:08:08.308 --> 00:08:10.682
And then lastly, data tampering.

162
00:08:10.682 --> 00:08:13.306
That if somebody has access
to your information,

163
00:08:13.306 --> 00:08:16.685
if they can get into the phone's data,
they can tamper with it.

164
00:08:16.685 --> 00:08:20.695
A Trojan horse is an example
where we modify an application to

165
00:08:20.695 --> 00:08:25.495
then phone home back to us and
send information, leak data, whatever,

166
00:08:25.495 --> 00:08:30.560
that we can tamper with the applications
on a phone or just our regular data.

167
00:08:30.560 --> 00:08:34.650
I might be having email records or other
files and folders stored on my phone.

168
00:08:34.650 --> 00:08:35.800
We can start to modify those records.

169
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:39.320
These are all risks that we have when
a phone is not properly secured and

170
00:08:39.320 --> 00:08:42.243
even a heavily secured phone
can be risked to some of this,

171
00:08:42.243 --> 00:08:43.867
if it's not secured properly.

172
00:08:43.867 --> 00:08:45.643
We have to keep it patched and updated and

173
00:08:45.643 --> 00:08:48.946
all the things that we know we're
supposed to do but a lot of people don't.

174
00:08:48.946 --> 00:08:49.566
>> Now, Don,

175
00:08:49.566 --> 00:08:53.690
you make it sound fairly dangerous to
actually have an unmanaged device.

176
00:08:53.690 --> 00:08:57.500
But don't the devices themselves have
some form of security that we can use?

177
00:08:57.500 --> 00:08:58.450
>> They do, right?

178
00:08:58.450 --> 00:09:01.180
So phones actually do a lot
to secure themselves.

179
00:09:01.180 --> 00:09:05.157
But in a unmanaged device, right, so if I
go to the store and I buy my own phone,

180
00:09:05.157 --> 00:09:06.019
I now manage it.

181
00:09:06.019 --> 00:09:08.250
Not my company, I do.

182
00:09:08.250 --> 00:09:12.720
And as the end user, I can start to
turn off those protections, right?

183
00:09:12.720 --> 00:09:14.566
Think about a lock screen.

184
00:09:14.566 --> 00:09:19.978
If I wanna unlock my phone, most phones
have a method of doing this, right?

185
00:09:19.978 --> 00:09:22.276
And it could be as simple as
not having a lock screen.

186
00:09:22.276 --> 00:09:25.292
You push the power button and
you're phone is on and now you're in and

187
00:09:25.292 --> 00:09:26.184
off you go, right?

188
00:09:26.184 --> 00:09:28.912
Or maybe it's a number pad, right?

189
00:09:28.912 --> 00:09:33.653
So you turn the phone on and you've gotta
punch in a code to be able to get in or

190
00:09:33.653 --> 00:09:35.840
draw a pattern, to get in.

191
00:09:35.840 --> 00:09:38.450
Or maybe it's a finger print scanner,
a little more advanced, right?

192
00:09:38.450 --> 00:09:39.680
That's what I use on my phone.

193
00:09:39.680 --> 00:09:42.550
So if I turn my phone on I've gotta
use my finger print to unlock it.

194
00:09:42.550 --> 00:09:43.950
That really helps secure it.

195
00:09:43.950 --> 00:09:47.650
If I lose my phone, I leave it in a cab
somewhere, somebody else could find it but

196
00:09:47.650 --> 00:09:49.830
unless they have my code,
they're not gonna get at my data?

197
00:09:49.830 --> 00:09:54.980
So that's safe but if it's my phone,
I can turn that off.

198
00:09:54.980 --> 00:09:56.190
I can turn the finger print scanner off.

199
00:09:56.190 --> 00:10:01.070
I can turn the number code lock off,
pattern lock, whatever it is.

200
00:10:01.070 --> 00:10:03.190
And in fact,
they're usually off by default.

201
00:10:03.190 --> 00:10:06.130
So phones take steps,
they take precautions but

202
00:10:06.130 --> 00:10:08.330
a lot of times users don't
take advantage of them.

203
00:10:08.330 --> 00:10:10.520
And that's where managing
the devices comes in.

204
00:10:10.520 --> 00:10:12.820
Because a company can come
in with a manage policy and

205
00:10:12.820 --> 00:10:17.600
they can say look, your phone has to
have a lock screen, it's required.

206
00:10:17.600 --> 00:10:21.680
And it has to use either a finger print or

207
00:10:21.680 --> 00:10:25.270
a six digit PIN, not a four digit,
a six digit, right?

208
00:10:25.270 --> 00:10:29.525
You can dictate policies like that and
your phone has to be encrypted.

209
00:10:29.525 --> 00:10:34.200
And you know that almost every phone sold
today supports encrypting the file system.

210
00:10:34.200 --> 00:10:36.060
But most of them don't
do it out of the box.

211
00:10:36.060 --> 00:10:38.550
And the reason they don't is for
performance.

212
00:10:38.550 --> 00:10:41.410
They want the phone to run fast so
when the user buys it at the store,

213
00:10:41.410 --> 00:10:46.030
they see this snappy new fancy phone
that runs nice and fast but if they turn

214
00:10:46.030 --> 00:10:49.170
on encryption, it's more secured which
runs a little bit slower, right?

215
00:10:49.170 --> 00:10:50.920
Well for a regular end user,

216
00:10:50.920 --> 00:10:54.820
they might not care about encryption, they
might not care, they want it to go fast.

217
00:10:54.820 --> 00:10:56.380
Versus a company which'll say, hey,

218
00:10:56.380 --> 00:10:59.280
we'll gladly sacrifice

00:23:14.858 --> 00:23:19.290

00:23:19.290 --> 00:23:21.940

it will say,okay give

00:23:21.940 --> 00:23:26.720

00:23:26.720 --> 00:23:30.571
So for example, if we were sharing

00:23:30.571 --> 00:23:34.881

00:23:34.881 --> 00:23:39.256

00:23:39.256 --> 00:23:42.480

00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:46.810
What you'd find in here is

454
00:23:46.810 --> 00:23:50.380

IOS would take the attachment and

455
00:23:50.380 --> 00:23:52.070

456
00:23:52.070 --> 00:23:55.250
And now that other application would
see this new incoming file and

457
00:23:55.250 --> 00:23:56.226
be able to act on it.

458
00:23:56.226 --> 00:23:57.549
Now notice what happens there,

459
00:23:57.549 --> 00:23:59.860
the two applications never
talk to each other, right?

460
00:23:59.860 --> 00:24:01.780
They don't talk to each other at all.

461
00:24:01.780 --> 00:24:06.890
They talk to iOS and iOS takes that file

462
00:24:06.890 --> 00:24:09.540
So you've always got this
Gatekeeper in between and

463
00:24:09.540 --> 00:24:12.470
that what preserves the Sandbox.

464
00:24:12.470 --> 00:24:17.330
If one application is fully compromised,
it's no big deal cuz it can't talk to

00:24:17.330 --> 00:24:21.590
any other application, it's isolated,
protected, and separated.

466
00:24:21.590 --> 00:24:24.550
And when you jailbreak a phone,

00:24:24.550 --> 00:24:26.330

00:24:26.330 --> 00:24:28.840
Notice how I'm just moving

00:24:28.840 --> 00:24:29.750

00:24:29.750 --> 00:24:31.500
I can touch all of these folders.

00:24:31.500 --> 00:24:33.470
And that's because this

00:24:33.470 --> 00:24:36.500

the walled garden that they call it.

00:24:36.500 --> 00:24:38.230

00:24:38.230 --> 00:24:41.190

00:24:41.190 --> 00:24:43.000

00:24:56.750 --> 00:25:00.240

I try and use as many devices as I can,

00:25:09.160 --> 00:25:14.690
the gatekeeper in between applications,

00:26:47.780 --> 00:26:53.370

00:27:38.010 --> 00:27:39.700

00:28:18.795 --> 00:28:22.040
In-between every single bit,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with the unmanaged device security by showing how Android devices isolate the similar to the iOS but also describe and show the big difference between them too.  Don then continues by describing the drawbacks of rooting and jailbreaking devices. 00:28:17.340 --> 00:28:20.940
So we have to have a lifecycle in our
company, a lifecycle where we dictate,

543
00:28:20.940 --> 00:28:23.540
even it if it's bring your own device,
that eventually,

544
00:28:23.540 --> 00:28:26.610
if your device is no longer
supported by the original vendor,

545
00:28:26.610 --> 00:28:28.920
then it's no longer supported
on the business network.

546
00:28:28.920 --> 00:28:31.640
That's all stuff that we have to
implement to protect our environment.

547
00:28:33.020 --> 00:28:35.450
>> All right, Don,
well that's a lot of information for

548
00:28:35.450 --> 00:28:39.370
us to consider when we have these
unmanaged mobile devices on our network.

549
00:28:39.370 --> 00:28:41.860
And it's something that we should
take a little bit of time and

550
00:28:41.860 --> 00:28:46.570
a little bit of effort to go into as
you start to get into the business and

551
00:28:46.570 --> 00:28:48.190
working with these devices.

552
00:28:48.190 --> 00:28:51.929
So running in this episode, Don really
did show us the way that Android,

553
00:28:51.929 --> 00:28:55.090
at this point,
how some of those protections built in.

554
00:28:55.090 --> 00:28:56.100
He also showed us,

555
00:28:56.100 --> 00:29:00.330
of course, the ability to see where the
attack is formulated and how that's done,

556
00:29:00.330 --> 00:29:03.650
and emphasize the importance of the
mitigations factors that we all have to

557
00:29:03.650 --> 00:29:07.380
consider, as we work with these devices
inside of our own managed environment.

558
00:29:07.380 --> 00:29:11.345
Unmanaged devices inside of our managed
environments, after this demonstration,

559
00:29:11.345 --> 00:29:13.667
seems like a bad idea,
Don, is all it seems like.

560
00:29:13.667 --> 00:29:17.180
>> [LAUGH] Well, I mean, it's the
difference between how we can use a device

561
00:29:17.180 --> 00:29:20.765
as consumer versus how we can use
a device in an enterprise organization.

562
00:29:20.765 --> 00:29:22.735
It's very different and
it really shouldn't be.

563
00:29:22.735 --> 00:29:26.615
As a consumer, we should be more security
conscious but most people aren't, right?

564
00:29:26.615 --> 00:29:29.950
But you have that luxury cuz if your
data gets compromised, it's just you.

565
00:29:29.950 --> 00:29:31.900
But in an enterprise,
if you get compromised,

566
00:29:31.900 --> 00:29:34.109
it's the entire enterprise
that gets compromised.

567
00:29:34.109 --> 00:29:37.162
So that's the big difference, it seems
scary but it's the reality of things.

568
00:29:37.162 --> 00:29:40.150
The risk is greater in
a corporate environment.

569
00:29:40.150 --> 00:29:43.590
>> All right, well that's a great
place for us to sign off then Don.

570
00:29:43.590 --> 00:29:46.950
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

571
00:29:46.950 --> 00:29:47.990
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

572
00:29:47.990 --> 00:29:51.430
>> Stay tuned right here for more emerging
technologies security demonstrations.

573
00:29:51.430 --> 00:29:57.697
[MUSIC]

574
00:29:57.697 --> 00:30:01.360
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the MDM-Mobile Device Management system. Its a service designed to allow companies to have a measure of control over devices it issues or that employees own by enrolling devices into that service.  According to Don, this enrollment allows us to create security and management policies for these device that can help secure devices that have company data on them.  He demonstrates not only the enrollment and policy creation but also the actions that can be taken when we discover a device maybe compromised.
episodes.title: Securing Devices with MDM
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.590
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.590 --> 00:00:06.374
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.374 --> 00:00:08.240
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.240 --> 00:00:12.050
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.050 --> 00:00:13.912
>> Welcome back to ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:13.912 --> 00:00:15.783
You're watching another segment

7
00:00:15.783 --> 00:00:18.626
on Emerging Technology
Security Demonstrations.

8
00:00:18.626 --> 00:00:23.867
We're specifically gonna be diving into
managing these devices with well, MDM.

9
00:00:23.867 --> 00:00:26.777
And here to help us out,
is gonna be Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.777 --> 00:00:29.720
Don, what in the world is an MDM?

11
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:31.843
>> [LAUGH] All right, if you've
been watching all of our episodes.

12
00:00:31.843 --> 00:00:36.164
In the last one we talked about the risks
of bringing a unmanaged device into your

13
00:00:36.164 --> 00:00:40.960
business, in your organization and all the
different things that that exposes you to.

14
00:00:40.960 --> 00:00:44.468
Well in this episode, we wanna talk
about one of the solutions to that, and

15
00:00:44.468 --> 00:00:46.938
that is Mobile Device Management or MDM.

16
00:00:46.938 --> 00:00:51.960
What MDM is,
is centralized software that can control

17
00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:56.100
these phones and tablets and other
devices that are coming on your network.

18
00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:59.584
These are devices that you dont
necessarily own that maybe the property of

19
00:00:59.584 --> 00:01:03.078
your employees or students or whoever
this participating in your network.

20
00:01:03.078 --> 00:01:07.060
But that will grant you the ability
to control certain aspects especially

21
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:09.870
security aspects of those devices.

22
00:01:09.870 --> 00:01:13.660
This is really critical because normally
when somebody brings their own phone and

23
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:17.570
joins in your wireless network,
you have no control over them at all.

24
00:01:17.570 --> 00:01:20.840
With an MDM, an MDM lets you
kind of create a partnership.

25
00:01:20.840 --> 00:01:24.320
A partnership between you and
that employee or you and that student,

26
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:28.560
or whoever to say, it's your phone,
you can have it, you can do what you want.

27
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:33.090
But you're gonna allow me to take a few
actions on the phone to be able to

28
00:01:33.090 --> 00:01:36.660
do things like remotely erase
the phone in case it gets lost or

29
00:01:36.660 --> 00:01:39.190
stolen, or
enforce a security policy on it.

30
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:40.520
You can still do what you want,

31
00:01:40.520 --> 00:01:44.030
but we're gonna impose these
rules upon it using the MDM.

32
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:47.486
That's what it does, and
it helps to reduce the risk of bringing

33
00:01:47.486 --> 00:01:51.779
in those unmanaged devices, but still
allow people to have their own systems.

34
00:01:51.779 --> 00:01:54.926
>> All right Don, so let's say that on
my network I've decided that that's

35
00:01:54.926 --> 00:01:58.720
what we wanna do, we wanna allow these
unmanaged devices to be on our network.

36
00:01:58.720 --> 00:02:02.160
You're giving me this idea that I
can do some type of control with it.

37
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:04.959
What do I need to do to get
implemented here and to get started?

38
00:02:04.959 --> 00:02:08.310
The first thing we need to do is we need
to pick an MDM, and there's a ton of them.

39
00:02:08.310 --> 00:02:11.921
If you do a Google search for MDM, you'll
find 30 different companies that make it.

40
00:02:11.921 --> 00:02:15.171
Many of them are free or
built into products you already have.

41
00:02:15.171 --> 00:02:18.280
So for example,
if you have Microsoft Exchange, and

42
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:20.779
you're using that for your email server.

43
00:02:20.779 --> 00:02:24.919
Exchange can actually do MDM, it can lock
down devices and remote erase and so on,

44
00:02:24.919 --> 00:02:28.040
for device that are connected
to the Exchange server.

45
00:02:28.040 --> 00:02:31.910
And it can manage iPhone and
Android as well as Windows mobile, so

46
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:35.410
it's actually very powerful for
that if you have Microsoft Exchange.

47
00:02:35.410 --> 00:02:39.630
Or if you are a all Apple environment,
and you have a Mac OS or

48
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:45.350
OS X server somewhere, inside of the OS X
server app, you can set up a MDM.

49
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:46.599
It's built into the server app.

50
00:02:46.599 --> 00:02:50.276
And again, you can lock down phones and
remote wipe them and so on,

51
00:02:50.276 --> 00:02:51.796
but it only works with iOS.

52
00:02:51.796 --> 00:02:55.871
That's kind of the trick, is you've got
to find a solution that manages all of

53
00:02:55.871 --> 00:02:58.669
the different devices that
you expect to encounter.

54
00:02:58.669 --> 00:03:03.270
Because if you even let one person go
unmanaged then everything falls apart,

55
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:03.780
right?

56
00:03:03.780 --> 00:03:06.302
Security is all about defense in-depth and

57
00:03:06.302 --> 00:03:09.991
your security is only as strong
as the weakest link in the chain.

58
00:03:09.991 --> 00:03:13.184
So if there's one little spot that
you allow somebody to get in and

59
00:03:13.184 --> 00:03:16.724
somebody comes in and say, hey,
look I've got this, I don't know,

60
00:03:16.724 --> 00:03:18.367
like a Nokia phone or something.

61
00:03:18.367 --> 00:03:21.152
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I don't wanna run Android or iOS,

62
00:03:21.152 --> 00:03:22.196
I wanna run this.

63
00:03:22.196 --> 00:03:25.260
And he say, all right,
well I guess I'll let you in unmanaged.

64
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:27.590
Well now that becomes an attack vector,
right?

65
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:29.017
Somebody could use that
to get in the system.

66
00:03:29.017 --> 00:03:31.804
So with an MDM we can enforce things like,
hey,

67
00:03:31.804 --> 00:03:35.780
we're not gonna give you a wireless
certificate unless you meet our

68
00:03:35.780 --> 00:03:40.540
requirements that you run this particular
OS or this version or higher and so on.

69
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:42.593
That's what the MDM does, right?

70
00:03:42.593 --> 00:03:45.790
So we need to select which one we're
going to use, and for this show,

71
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:49.944
just as a demonstration, I'm gonna use a
product called AirWatch, it's from VMware.

72
00:03:49.944 --> 00:03:52.302
VMware's known for
their virtualization platform.

73
00:03:52.302 --> 00:03:55.550
I like AirWatch because it's quick and
easy, it's web based.

74
00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:58.470
It runs on their systems,
software as a service.

75
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:00.897
So you can go to the AirWatch website,
set up a demo and be up and

76
00:04:00.897 --> 00:04:01.892
running in ten minutes.

77
00:04:01.892 --> 00:04:04.394
And after that,
we just need to connect our devices to it,

78
00:04:04.394 --> 00:04:05.989
we can start managing them, right?

79
00:04:05.989 --> 00:04:10.630
And that act of connecting a device
to your MDM, that's called enrolling.

80
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:14.010
We enroll a device to
be centrally managed.

81
00:04:14.010 --> 00:04:17.667
And the important thing here is
that if it's a customer device,

82
00:04:17.667 --> 00:04:19.372
they can choose to unenroll.

83
00:04:19.372 --> 00:04:21.730
All right, they can say I don't
want to be maintenance anymore, and

84
00:04:21.730 --> 00:04:22.710
they can unenroll.

85
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:26.859
Now when that happens, we can take a few
actions, like we can remove things.

86
00:04:26.859 --> 00:04:27.567
For example,

87
00:04:27.567 --> 00:04:31.698
if I have a wireless network that requires
a certificate to be able to join, right?

88
00:04:31.698 --> 00:04:34.819
If it's doing WPA2 Enterprise,
well I can say,

89
00:04:34.819 --> 00:04:38.180
when you enroll I give
you the certificate.

90
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:40.690
And then as soon as you unenroll I
take the certificate away, right?

91
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:41.960
And MDM can do that.

92
00:04:41.960 --> 00:04:44.370
So now they're no longer able to
participate on your wireless network and

93
00:04:44.370 --> 00:04:45.190
they're on their own.

94
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:47.980
It's their own phone, they can do
whatever they want with it, right?

95
00:04:47.980 --> 00:04:49.638
But if they don't let
you centrally manage it,

96
00:04:49.638 --> 00:04:51.428
you're not gonna let them on the network,
right?

97
00:04:51.428 --> 00:04:54.480
This is the only way that we
can have a secure network, and

98
00:04:54.480 --> 00:04:57.730
still allow people to have
their own devices, right?

99
00:04:57.730 --> 00:04:59.615
So we need to get those devices enrolled,
and

100
00:04:59.615 --> 00:05:01.310
that's what I wanna show you guys here.

101
00:05:01.310 --> 00:05:04.550
I wanna take a device and get it enrolled
to be managed, and the process is usually

102
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:07.188
pretty painless, but
different products work different ways.

103
00:05:07.188 --> 00:05:11.466
For example, Microsoft Exchange when you
launch Outlook on the phone and you login

104
00:05:11.466 --> 00:05:15.639
to the Exchange Server the first time,
it automatically enrolls it in that MDM.

105
00:05:15.639 --> 00:05:18.200
So it's done through the email client for
that.

106
00:05:18.200 --> 00:05:22.110
But for AirWatch and for
most of the others, they use an agent, and

107
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:24.660
agent that has to be
installed on the phone.

108
00:05:24.660 --> 00:05:27.525
Now I'm logged into the AirWatch
control panel here, so

109
00:05:27.525 --> 00:05:29.560
this is what the central hub looks like.

110
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:33.709
So as an administrator, I sit down I log
in and I can see a quick status of my

111
00:05:33.709 --> 00:05:38.146
devices, how many devices I got registered
and I can start to work with them.

112
00:05:38.146 --> 00:05:40.270
Well I want to enroll a new device, right?

113
00:05:40.270 --> 00:05:44.197
So Bob, and accounting comes in and says,
hey, I got a new phone, it's awesome!

114
00:05:44.197 --> 00:05:46.440
Can I use them on the company network?

115
00:05:46.440 --> 00:05:47.109
And we say, all right, well yes.

116
00:05:47.109 --> 00:05:51.320
Yes, you can, if you enroll it for us to
be able to manage the security policy.

117
00:05:51.320 --> 00:05:53.371
Bob says hey,
I'm fine with that let's do it.

118
00:05:53.371 --> 00:05:56.730
All right, we'll just go up here
to add and I'm gonna add a device.

119
00:05:57.900 --> 00:06:01.960
And when I add that device, I just need to
come through and tie it to a user, right.

120
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:04.138
So I would have Bob to find my system.

121
00:06:04.138 --> 00:06:06.720
AirWatch ties into Active Directory and
a few other things.

122
00:06:06.720 --> 00:06:08.180
So if you have a user database in there,

123
00:06:08.180 --> 00:06:11.080
I've just got a sample user
database I'll pick myself here.

124
00:06:11.080 --> 00:06:15.160
So I'm going to pick, me,
and then I'll come down and

125
00:06:15.160 --> 00:06:18.050
specify information about the device,
right?

126
00:06:18.050 --> 00:06:20.927
So I'm gonna call this one,
I will call it Don's iPhone or

127
00:06:20.927 --> 00:06:23.649
whatever happens to be,
this is just a friendly name.

128
00:06:23.649 --> 00:06:27.702
So I can remember what it is, so I'll call
it Don's iPhone, it's part of ITPro.TV,

129
00:06:27.702 --> 00:06:30.130
and then here is the important thing.

130
00:06:30.130 --> 00:06:34.527
I need to pick whether it's corporate
dedicated, corporate shared or

131
00:06:34.527 --> 00:06:36.150
employee owned, right?

132
00:06:36.150 --> 00:06:39.020
Now what's the difference on this?

133
00:06:39.020 --> 00:06:44.130
Well, I might want to allow
somebody who owns their own phone,

134
00:06:44.130 --> 00:06:47.430
I might want them to be able to unenroll,
right?

135
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:51.830
So if Bob decides hey, I dont wanna
use it on the company network anymore,

136
00:06:51.830 --> 00:06:53.620
he can choose to unenroll.

137
00:06:53.620 --> 00:06:57.688
But if the company bought the phone, if we
bought it, that is corporate dedicated.

138
00:06:57.688 --> 00:06:59.966
We just bought it for the company, and so

139
00:06:59.966 --> 00:07:02.517
I don't want to allow
that to be unenrolled.

140
00:07:02.517 --> 00:07:05.537
It's always gonna be apart of the MDM.

141
00:07:05.537 --> 00:07:10.677
Or if it's corporate shared,
now it's both environments, right?

142
00:07:10.677 --> 00:07:13.900
It's maybe an employee owned phone,
but it's being used by the company or

143
00:07:13.900 --> 00:07:14.728
we split the cost.

144
00:07:14.728 --> 00:07:17.958
And I might have a different policy there
that may or may not allow an enrollment or

145
00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.160
other things, right?

146
00:07:19.160 --> 00:07:21.228
So you can set different
policies based on what you want.

147
00:07:21.228 --> 00:07:25.280
I'm gonna designate that we'll go
corporate dedicated on this phone, right?

148
00:07:25.280 --> 00:07:28.469
So this phone is just straight
up a corporate phone, okay?

149
00:07:28.469 --> 00:07:30.040
And then I can designate a platform.

150
00:07:30.040 --> 00:07:32.517
Now AirWatch is really flexible,
it supports a ton of platforms.

151
00:07:32.517 --> 00:07:36.499
So I could leave this empty, but if I drop
that down you'll see where I can pick from

152
00:07:36.499 --> 00:07:39.349
all of the ones that they support and
they support a bunch.

153
00:07:39.349 --> 00:07:43.618
Android, iOS, macOS, tvOS so
you can manage the Apple TVs,

154
00:07:43.618 --> 00:07:47.248
Blackberries, all sorts of stuff in here,
right?

155
00:07:47.248 --> 00:07:51.850
Well in my case, I'm talking about
an iPhone, so I would pick Apple iOS.

156
00:07:51.850 --> 00:07:53.840
But you might have an Android phone or
something else, and

157
00:07:53.840 --> 00:07:55.270
you would choose what platform.

158
00:07:55.270 --> 00:07:56.564
Now why does that matter?

159
00:07:56.564 --> 00:08:00.928
What matters here is that with MDM we're
reaching out and talking to the phone and

160
00:08:00.928 --> 00:08:03.186
trying to implement security features.

161
00:08:03.186 --> 00:08:06.883
Well, there's some security features
on Android that aren't on iOS.

162
00:08:06.883 --> 00:08:09.820
And there's some security features
on iOS that aren't on Android.

163
00:08:09.820 --> 00:08:12.400
For example, iCloud Lock,
with iCloud Lock,

164
00:08:12.400 --> 00:08:15.880
I'm logged into an iPhone
with an iTunes account.

165
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:20.710
And then, if the phone ever gets stolen,
nobody can factory reset it and

166
00:08:20.710 --> 00:08:23.030
reprovision it,
unless they have my iTunes account, right?

167
00:08:23.030 --> 00:08:25.380
So that's an activation lock
that's a part of that phone.

168
00:08:25.380 --> 00:08:28.520
We don't have that on Android,
that's on iPhone right?

169
00:08:28.520 --> 00:08:30.650
So on Android we have different
things to do activation lock.

170
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:34.300
And so each one kinda has a different
model, so we can designate that here.

171
00:08:34.300 --> 00:08:38.960
Now, I dont actually have to
designate this or even get it right,

172
00:08:38.960 --> 00:08:40.770
I could have left it at any.

173
00:08:40.770 --> 00:08:44.060
And when the device enrolls it will
detect it and apply it properly.

174
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:47.140
So while it is a required field,
I could have left it at any and

175
00:08:47.140 --> 00:08:47.880
it wold have been fine.

176
00:08:49.310 --> 00:08:53.050
Now, once that's done, I can save that and

177
00:08:53.050 --> 00:08:56.590
it's got where we can do messaging to send
people a message about it being enrolled.

178
00:08:56.590 --> 00:08:58.840
Cuz they need to attach it on their end,
right?

179
00:08:58.840 --> 00:09:02.020
But, in my case, I'm gonna use something
on screen to be able to do this, so

180
00:09:02.020 --> 00:09:03.310
I'll go ahead and save that.

181
00:09:03.310 --> 00:09:07.880
And, what's gonna happen is,
that user is going to receive an email or

182
00:09:07.880 --> 00:09:12.000
a text message, or whatever method
it is I choose to communicate it.

183
00:09:12.000 --> 00:09:14.240
And when they do,
it's going to have a link in there,

184
00:09:14.240 --> 00:09:17.870
that will let them attach

00:20:30.220 --> 00:20:32.265
All right, well I forgot my phone.

409
00:20:32.265 --> 00:20:36.323
Well if the phone is lost,
we can take that device, and

410
00:20:36.323 --> 00:20:38.540
we can do stuff to it, right?

411
00:20:38.540 --> 00:20:39.630
We can lock it, right?

412
00:20:39.630 --> 00:20:44.742
If I want to lock the phone, I can come in
here and lock it, and now no one will be

413
00:20:44.742 --> 00:20:49.959
able to access the phone until I come in
here and unlock it from the MDM, right?

414
00:20:49.959 --> 00:20:51.883
So that's one thing that we can do.

415
00:20:51.883 --> 00:20:54.647
You can also pull
the location of the device,

416
00:20:54.647 --> 00:20:59.610
we can do a request device check in and
that'll let help to find that device.

417
00:20:59.610 --> 00:21:03.000
Find the device will also let me make
a noise, so it can send off some beeps and

418
00:21:03.000 --> 00:21:04.650
maybe we can locate it that way.

419
00:21:04.650 --> 00:21:09.148
But the odds are if we've lost that phone,
if somebody physically gets it,

420
00:21:09.148 --> 00:21:10.483
even if it's locked,

421
00:21:10.483 --> 00:21:15.211
there might be an exploit they can take
advantage of to get the data on the phone.

422
00:21:15.211 --> 00:21:18.795
So what we're normally going to
want is to do an Enterprise Wipe.

423
00:21:18.795 --> 00:21:21.498
An Enterprise Wipe is where we
just come in and we just say,

424
00:21:21.498 --> 00:21:23.553
look, I need to get all
my data off of there.

425
00:21:23.553 --> 00:21:26.303
Now that's a little different,
than a factory reset,

426
00:21:26.303 --> 00:21:28.480
where we just completely erase the device.

427
00:21:28.480 --> 00:21:34.380
Now, the reason they differentiate here,
is if it's an employee owned phone.

428
00:21:34.380 --> 00:21:36.426
So if it's there personal phone and
they lose it,

429
00:21:36.426 --> 00:21:39.250
we don't want to erase all of
the data that's on it, right?

430
00:21:39.250 --> 00:21:42.429
They might have data on it that's theirs
like photos they took of their kids, and

431
00:21:42.429 --> 00:21:43.609
you don't want to lose that.

432
00:21:43.609 --> 00:21:47.147
So we choose Enterprise Wipe,
it's wiping your corporate data,

433
00:21:47.147 --> 00:21:50.053
the data that you have that's
a part of that phone, and

434
00:21:50.053 --> 00:21:52.913
so what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna take my phone here.

435
00:21:52.913 --> 00:21:58.340
I'm just gnna mirror that back up again,
and once I get that back online.

436
00:21:58.340 --> 00:22:02.091
I'm gonna send it in Enterprise Wipe
signal to just basically erase that

437
00:22:02.091 --> 00:22:04.510
corporate data right off of it, okay?

438
00:22:04.510 --> 00:22:06.420
So let me punch that in.

439
00:22:06.420 --> 00:22:07.200
There we go.

440
00:22:07.200 --> 00:22:11.930
So here's my phone, and
I'm gonna send the Enterprise Wipe signal.

441
00:22:11.930 --> 00:22:14.890
And when I send it,
I can prevent re-enrollment,

442
00:22:14.890 --> 00:22:18.040
which would stop somebody from
attaching it back to the MDM again.

443
00:22:18.040 --> 00:22:20.540
If this is an employee that we've
terminated, for example, and

444
00:22:20.540 --> 00:22:22.200
they still have a valid username and
password.

445
00:22:22.200 --> 00:22:25.060
Well that's my first mistake, but
I could prevent it from re-enrolling and

446
00:22:25.060 --> 00:22:26.800
that would stop them from getting back in.

447
00:22:26.800 --> 00:22:29.103
But otherwise, we can come in and

448
00:22:29.103 --> 00:22:32.983
we can punch in what the security pin for
that device is.

449
00:22:32.983 --> 00:22:33.633
There we go.

450
00:22:33.633 --> 00:22:37.207
Actually it's the security
PIN from my administrator.

451
00:22:37.207 --> 00:22:39.590
Now it's sending the remote wipe.

452
00:22:39.590 --> 00:22:44.542
And as I watch on my device, what's gonna
happen is the next time the agent connects

453
00:22:44.542 --> 00:22:49.525
in, it's gonna generate that signal and
it's going to initiate the remote wipe.

454
00:22:49.525 --> 00:22:52.400
Now notice how it's not
taking effect right away.

455
00:22:52.400 --> 00:22:55.580
These remote wipes,
they do a push notification.

456
00:22:55.580 --> 00:22:59.367
But the push notification for Apple
device is actually bounced through Apple.

457
00:22:59.367 --> 00:23:02.849
And so it can take a moment for
it to basically bounce through Apple and

458
00:23:02.849 --> 00:23:04.550
then get down to the phone.

459
00:23:04.550 --> 00:23:08.430
But the next time the phone checks
in it'll initiate the remote wipe.

460
00:23:08.430 --> 00:23:11.890
Now I'm gonna just launch the app here
to cause it to happen right away.

461
00:23:11.890 --> 00:23:14.780
And see how it's doing the please
ensure all enrollment and

462
00:23:14.780 --> 00:23:16.210
an enrollment is in progress.

463
00:23:16.210 --> 00:23:19.150
It's not actually in progress,
it's erasing,

464
00:23:19.150 --> 00:23:22.169
it's stripping out that
employee data right now.

465
00:23:22.169 --> 00:23:25.383
And so it's kind of doing that in the
background and just kind of waiting for

466
00:23:25.383 --> 00:23:26.600
that to complete.

467
00:23:26.600 --> 00:23:31.420
But that process is taking place, and it's
to securely erase the enterprise data.

468
00:23:31.420 --> 00:23:34.816
And as soon as it's done, my device
will be unenrolled, and it will no

469
00:23:34.816 --> 00:23:38.744
longer be a part of the company, but it'll
also no longer have the company data.

470
00:23:38.744 --> 00:23:40.680
The certificates gets removed and so on.

471
00:23:40.680 --> 00:23:41.960
And in this case that's gonna happen and

472
00:23:41.960 --> 00:23:44.670
we don't really notice anything
going on on the phone, right?

473
00:23:44.670 --> 00:23:49.170
The phone is behaving like normal,
and for a few different reason, right?

474
00:23:49.170 --> 00:23:51.804
The main reason here is if this
is employee's been terminated,

475
00:23:51.804 --> 00:23:54.411
you don't want it to look like
you're scrubbing their phone.

476
00:23:54.411 --> 00:23:56.220
So it's all being done in the background.

477
00:23:56.220 --> 00:24:00.270
Everything looks normal to them, meanwhile
the company data has been removed, right?

478
00:24:00.270 --> 00:24:03.790
If we had done a lock instead,
that's very obvious.

479
00:24:03.790 --> 00:24:07.290
When you go and lock the device, you can
display a message on the screen that says,

480
00:24:07.290 --> 00:24:10.565
if you find this device please call
this number, here's a reward, right?

481
00:24:10.565 --> 00:24:12.870
We'll pay you to give it back,
that's very obvious.

482
00:24:12.870 --> 00:24:14.190
That's what we want there.

483
00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:16.130
But when it's employee termination or
a lost phone,

484
00:24:16.130 --> 00:24:17.890
you want it to be fairly transparent.

485
00:24:17.890 --> 00:24:20.070
And that's where
the Enterprise Wipe comes in.

486
00:24:20.070 --> 00:24:23.584
So those are all things that we're
able to do when we have an MDM.

487
00:24:23.584 --> 00:24:27.659
We have control of these devices,
even though they're employee owned or

488
00:24:27.659 --> 00:24:31.180
not things that we
actually bought ourselves.

489
00:24:31.180 --> 00:24:35.320
>> All right Don, well thank you for
helping clarify what an MDM is for us.

490
00:24:35.320 --> 00:24:38.714
And for helping us to be able to see
the power behind using an MDM for

491
00:24:38.714 --> 00:24:42.174
our networks and of course,
these unmanaged mobile devices, and

492
00:24:42.174 --> 00:24:44.185
the control that we have behind them.

493
00:24:44.185 --> 00:24:47.808
Remember that what you did see here of
course is the enrollment process as well

494
00:24:47.808 --> 00:24:48.878
as choosing that MDM.

495
00:24:48.878 --> 00:24:52.969
And then lastly, the actions that we can
take with it which are very powerful and

496
00:24:52.969 --> 00:24:55.899
allow us to make sure that our
data is a bit more secure than

497
00:24:55.899 --> 00:24:58.126
just having those devices on our network.

498
00:24:58.126 --> 00:25:02.250
Thank you again Don, for showing us
that and thank you also for watching.

499
00:25:02.250 --> 00:25:06.320
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

500
00:25:06.320 --> 00:25:07.187
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

501
00:25:07.187 --> 00:25:11.411
>> Stay tuned right here for more Emerging
Technology Security Demonstrations.

502
00:25:11.411 --> 00:25:17.833
[MUSIC]

503
00:25:17.833 --> 00:25:21.513
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this segment, Ronnie and Don demonstrate how to setup a man-in-the-middle attack, how to capture the data and then discuss how to mitigate it as well.  Don shows how to setup a rogue access point using a wireless access point.  Next they demonstrate how to implement port mirroring and using Wireshark to capture the data without the end-users knowledge.  Lastly, they demonstrate and discuss several mitigation strategies against man-in-the-middle attacks.
episodes.title: Man in the Middle Attacks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITPROTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:04.651
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:04.651 --> 00:00:07.750
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.750 --> 00:00:08.332
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

5
00:00:08.332 --> 00:00:13.530
>> Welcome to ITProTV.

6
00:00:13.530 --> 00:00:17.730
You're watching emerging
technologies security demonstration.

7
00:00:17.730 --> 00:00:19.630
I'll be your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:19.630 --> 00:00:22.480
And today, we're going to be learning
specifically about man in the middle

9
00:00:22.480 --> 00:00:25.660
attacks with the demonstration here by Mr.
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.660 --> 00:00:27.200
Don, what are we actually
gonna take a look at?

11
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:28.580
And how we gonna demonstrate this?

12
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:31.480
>> All right, well one of the challenges
we have with mobile devices like cell

13
00:00:31.480 --> 00:00:35.240
phones and tablets, is that they're
almost all wireless, right?

14
00:00:35.240 --> 00:00:37.210
If you get an iPad, or

15
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:39.670
an Android phone, they don't have
physical network jacks on them.

16
00:00:39.670 --> 00:00:41.560
Cuz they rely on wireless networks.

17
00:00:41.560 --> 00:00:45.330
And unfortunately,
wireless networks are very easy to spoof.

18
00:00:45.330 --> 00:00:48.460
So, an attacker can come in and
spoof wireless network,

19
00:00:48.460 --> 00:00:50.363
mobile devices will jump onto it.

20
00:00:50.363 --> 00:00:54.910
And now the mobile devices are passing
through a network the attacker controls.

21
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:58.640
That means the attacker can intercept and
even in some cases modify and

22
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:00.590
tamper with the traffic
as it passes through.

23
00:01:00.590 --> 00:01:02.880
But that's performing a man
in the middle attack.

24
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:06.270
So that's what we'll be taking
a look right here in this episode.

25
00:01:06.270 --> 00:01:08.530
So, let me just start off a little diagram
to make sure everybody's kind of on

26
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:10.300
the same page of where
we're going on this.

27
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:13.050
Here's a typical network that
you'll see in an organization.

28
00:01:13.050 --> 00:01:16.100
Where you've got a router that's
providing Internet access.

29
00:01:16.100 --> 00:01:18.860
You got a switch which might
be built into the router.

30
00:01:18.860 --> 00:01:20.000
It might be separate.

31
00:01:20.000 --> 00:01:21.170
And you've got an access point.

32
00:01:21.170 --> 00:01:24.900
Again, in a home environment all
three of these might be one device.

33
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:27.740
In a corporate or enterprise environment
they're going to be separate distinct

34
00:01:27.740 --> 00:01:30.320
devices, each one
providing a different role.

35
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:32.840
Now the one I'm concentrating on
right now is the access point.

36
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:34.960
The access point is creating
a wireless network and

37
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:37.570
the wireless network has an identifier,
an SSID.

38
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:39.260
A service set identifier.

39
00:01:39.260 --> 00:01:41.820
And when people connect to the wireless
network they need to know that name.

40
00:01:41.820 --> 00:01:44.940
And they also need to
know how to authenticate.

41
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:47.493
It could be that
authentication turned off,

42
00:01:47.493 --> 00:01:49.853
could just be a public wireless network.

43
00:01:49.853 --> 00:01:55.024
Or it could be one where you have a SSID
coupled with a password, a pre-shared key.

44
00:01:55.024 --> 00:01:58.870
And then the third method is, we have
an SSID coupled with a certificate,

45
00:01:58.870 --> 00:02:01.116
just certificate based authentication.

46
00:02:01.116 --> 00:02:02.439
That's the strongest one.

47
00:02:02.439 --> 00:02:05.890
That one is very, very difficult to spoof.

48
00:02:05.890 --> 00:02:09.185
But no password and pre-shared key,
are the two most common.

49
00:02:09.185 --> 00:02:12.160
And they're incredibly easy to spoof.

50
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:16.380
So as an example, let's say this
is a coffee shop like a Starbucks.

51
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:19.529
Then when you walk into Starbucks, they
have right there on the wall the SSID and

52
00:02:19.529 --> 00:02:20.288
pre-shared key.

53
00:02:20.288 --> 00:02:22.600
The password you use to log into it.

54
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:24.086
Well, an attacker could
take that information.

55
00:02:24.086 --> 00:02:27.210
Cuz they know it, it's public.

56
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:32.670
And then they can bring up their own
access point, a rogue access point.

57
00:02:32.670 --> 00:02:34.910
And then,
when they bring up a rogue access point,

58
00:02:34.910 --> 00:02:37.910
they can give it any SSID they want.

59
00:02:37.910 --> 00:02:44.640
Including the same SSID that's already in
use by the private WiFi for that network.

60
00:02:44.640 --> 00:02:48.350
And when they do that,
devices will not know the difference.

61
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:48.960
They'll see it.

62
00:02:48.960 --> 00:02:52.640
It will be the same SSID, same password,
they won't know the difference.

63
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:56.390
And they'll start switching over and
jumping on to that other network.

64
00:02:57.480 --> 00:03:01.190
Now, that process happens
invisible to the users.

65
00:03:01.190 --> 00:03:03.450
And depending on how the rogue
access point is set up.

66
00:03:03.450 --> 00:03:07.270
That can be completely invisible to
them and very difficult to detect.

67
00:03:07.270 --> 00:03:08.250
Now in my diagram here,

68
00:03:08.250 --> 00:03:11.142
I'm showing an access point that's
physically wired into a switch.

69
00:03:11.142 --> 00:03:14.821
A lot of schools, a lot of corporations,
they move equipment around and

70
00:03:14.821 --> 00:03:17.870
they leave wall jacks
exposed in various places.

71
00:03:17.870 --> 00:03:20.480
If you find that, that's like hacker gold.

72
00:03:20.480 --> 00:03:22.970
Because they can take an access point,
plug right into the wall.

73
00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:25.757
And now they can attack the traffic
as it's passing through to

74
00:03:25.757 --> 00:03:26.783
the regular network.

75
00:03:26.783 --> 00:03:28.900
End users don't even know what happened.

76
00:03:28.900 --> 00:03:32.035
But even without a physical
connection you can get access points.

77
00:03:32.035 --> 00:03:36.600
This ones like the Anonabox, that will let
you connect to a wireless access point.

78
00:03:36.600 --> 00:03:39.840
While providing your own as two
sets of antennas inside of it.

79
00:03:39.840 --> 00:03:41.720
And those devices are under $100.

80
00:03:41.720 --> 00:03:45.650
So it doesn't take a lot of money to
build up an attack profile like this.

81
00:03:45.650 --> 00:03:47.880
That makes it very easy to exploit and

82
00:03:47.880 --> 00:03:51.070
a very big risk if you're
managing mobile devices.

83
00:03:51.070 --> 00:03:53.460
All right, well let's see this in action.

84
00:03:53.460 --> 00:03:55.347
We've got an access point sitting
here on the table with us.

85
00:03:55.347 --> 00:03:57.574
And this little access point is
kind of an interesting one for

86
00:03:57.574 --> 00:03:58.542
a few different reasons.

87
00:03:58.542 --> 00:04:03.130
One it's cheap,
I think it cost again maybe a $100 tops.

88
00:04:03.130 --> 00:04:08.030
But the other thing is it looks like
a fire detector, like a smoke detector.

89
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:09.950
So it's a very easy to disguise one.

90
00:04:09.950 --> 00:04:13.100
So you could take this somewhere and
drop it off and forget about it.

91
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:14.650
There's companies that
specialize in that too.

92
00:04:14.650 --> 00:04:18.270
Like Pony Express, where they specialize
in making devices that you can plug in.

93
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:21.510
And they kinda disguise
themselves in the environment.

94
00:04:21.510 --> 00:04:26.410
Meanwhile, they're creating a rogue access
point and starting to hijack traffic.

95
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:29.484
So, if I wanna set this access point up
to hijack traffic the first thing I need

96
00:04:29.484 --> 00:04:30.916
to do is I need to get logged in to it.

97
00:04:30.916 --> 00:04:33.857
So, let me connect into that
access point real quick.

98
00:04:33.857 --> 00:04:38.574
And I know that we have a network
right here in building that

99
00:04:38.574 --> 00:04:40.660
people can connect to.

100
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:45.810
That is a public network that
is available for people to use.

101
00:04:45.810 --> 00:04:48.340
And all I have to do is come in here and

102
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:51.140
modified the wireless
network in this access point.

103
00:04:51.140 --> 00:04:54.280
And I just need to get it to match
what's being used in production.

104
00:04:54.280 --> 00:04:56.420
So that's not such a challenge.

105
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:59.040
So in my production network,
I've got an SSID name.

106
00:04:59.040 --> 00:05:02.060
So I'm gonna take my SSID here,
and I'll modify that.

107
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:07.420
And I'm just gonna put in, ours is just
called ITProTV, or Starbucks, or whatever.

108
00:05:07.420 --> 00:05:10.110
And then I come down here and
I set my security mode.

109
00:05:10.110 --> 00:05:14.870
Now if it's a open network with no
password on it, I'm actually done,

110
00:05:14.870 --> 00:05:16.380
that's enough, right?

111
00:05:16.380 --> 00:05:18.710
But if there is a password,
I need to come in and set it.

112
00:05:18.710 --> 00:05:21.210
I need to try and
match whatever's being used in production.

113
00:05:21.210 --> 00:05:25.470
Now, heres the thing, if there's
no password, that's easy to spoof.

114
00:05:25.470 --> 00:05:29.140
If there's a pre-shared key,
that's easy to spoof.

115
00:05:29.140 --> 00:05:30.620
But the enterprise modes,

116
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:33.840
these guys down here at the bottom,
those use certificates.

117
00:05:33.840 --> 00:05:36.710
And certificate based
authentication can't be spoofed.

118
00:05:36.710 --> 00:05:38.080
That's the way you mitigate this attack.

119
00:05:38.080 --> 00:05:39.430
That's the way you defeat it, right?

120
00:05:39.430 --> 00:05:43.735
Certificates, that's where we use
802.1X authentication and E.A.P,

121
00:05:43.735 --> 00:05:46.230
which combined is what creates WPA2.

122
00:05:46.230 --> 00:05:49.860
And WPA2 says when you connect you
gotta present a certificate to me.

123
00:05:49.860 --> 00:05:52.500
And I'm gonna run that against
the certificate authority and

124
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:55.220
verify if it's allowed and
see if you can connect in.

125
00:05:55.220 --> 00:05:59.270
If I'm spoofing this network,
I don't have access to the CA.

126
00:05:59.270 --> 00:06:02.480
I can't use the certificate for
validation, I can't do any of that.

127
00:06:02.480 --> 00:06:04.680
And that means the client is
